Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Scaling-up Cooperation across Cultural Groups

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Coordinated inter-group cooperation is essential for resolving many major social and environmental issues. From managing fisheries to controlling disease epidemics, solving big problems requires collective action. However, promoting large-scale cooperation among distinct groups such as nations can be difficult. One reason may lie in our basic nature as human beings. If, as some evolutionary theorists believe, we evolved to cooperate with members of our own small groups and compete against members of other groups, then cooperation across national and cultural group boundaries is uniquely challenging. Past research has focused on within-group cooperative interactions. Now the question is whether the mechanisms known to promote within-group cooperation can also promote cooperation among groups with different cultural backgrounds and traditions. Answering this question is complicated by the fact that scaling up from one level of organization to another generally produces new and unpredictable properties. Therefore, it is necessary to conduct research that specifically addresses inter-group cooperation. In the research supported by this award, post-doctoral scholars Dr. Caitlin A. Stern (Santa Fe Institute) and Dr. Jessica L. Barker (University of Arizona) will do exactly that. They will investigate experimentally whether mechanisms, such as reputation and the potential for punishment, that are known to promote within-group cooperation can also promote cooperation between groups.

The research will be carried out among the Tlingit tribes of Southeast Alaska. The Tlingit operate fisheries both independently and inter-dependently with other tribes, representing a microcosm of the interactions among distinct cultural groups that must be understood in order to solve trans-boundary collective action issues. In collaboration with Native Alaskan organizations, the researchers will conduct empirical studies (experimental "games" within and between groups, as well as cultural surveys) in Juneau and Haines, Alaska. The researchers will also construct mathematical models of how different factors might affect cooperative behavior, which can be tested against the empirical data. Together, the empirical and theoretical components of this study will illuminate how cultural heterogeneities influence the maintenance of cooperation, and will advance our understanding of the global cooperation necessary to solve large-scale, multi-group collective action issues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When you need help, who do you ask? A friend or family member? Does who you ask depend on what you need help with?

Helping and similar behavior that benefits others (often called "cooperation") is a focus of research in many disciplines, from anthropology, psychology, and economics to evolutionary biology and behavioral ecology. This research has revealed that people tend to cooperate with others with whom they share some aspect of group identity, but the situations in which people identifying with different groups might cooperate with each other largely remain overlooked. Much of the research on cooperation has been carried out using economic experiments with undergraduate students, which means much of our knowledge comes from a homogeneous sample of people making decisions about abstract scenarios.

This project set out to challenge these limitations. We carried out a survey, an economic game, and interviews with Tlingit, Haida, Tsimshian and other Native tribes from Southeast Alaska.  The outcomes of these surveys are described below through the NSF merit review criteria of intellectual merit and broader impacts.

The intellectual merit of the project was to investigate when people are willing to cooperate with people from other groups since this is a question that has been ignored in most academic research (which has focused instead on cooperation with people from the same group, and conflict between groups). For example, the Tlingit and Haida have a long history of both cooperation and conflict within and between clans, and a lot of this history is in danger of being lost. Clans are family-based groupings that historically shaped many aspects of life, from who one could marry to who would organize one's funeral. If we can document practices surrounding cooperation between clans, not only can this heritage be perpetuated but also we can learn something more generally about cooperation between distinct groups.

The broader impacts of the project were to document Alaska Native cultural practices surrounding cooperation and helping other people in different situations in everyday life. One reason for doing this is to help perpetuate Native cultural heritage (for example, many participants told us stories about situations involving helping others), and in particular to showcase some of the positive aspects of Native life when so much research focuses on the negatives. (In many cases this is for important reasons, e.g. to develop better care for people suffering from medical issues, but it can mean the positive parts are overlooked.) Another reason is to connect with people who may not be engaged in the more traditional Native practices, but still strongly engage with Native values of helping others in the community, and do so in their own way in their everyday lives.

The project involved two rounds of data collection, during which the Sealaska Heritage Institution (a Native-run nonprofit in Juneau) generously gave us logistical support. Our primary means of recruiting participants was at Celebration, a biennial festival of Southeast Alaska Native culture. We carried out surveys at Celebration 2016, as well as with additional participants in Juneau, Haines, and Klukwan; we returned to Celebration in 2018 to run economic games and interviews. Thanks to the fantastic work of our Native student researchers, we collected so much data that our analyses are still ongoing.

A report with preliminary findings from the survey is posted on the Sealaska Heritage Institute website (http://www.sealaskaheritage.org/institute/culture-and-history/programs/visiting-scholars). We found that both clan and community identity matter to people when helping others, and that shared community identity mattered more than shared clan identity. Preliminary data from the economic game suggest that shared clan membership is important for promoting cooperative decisions in the context of fishing when people are in the same community. The results from the survey will allow us to put these results in context in order to understand how clan, community and other aspects of shared identity relate to cooperation in different scenarios. Underpinning all of these scenarios, however, is the emergence of helping others as a core value in Alaska Native culture. We explore this further in a blog post shortly to be published on the Sealaska Heritage Institute website.
